questions.question: In a multi-account, multi-VPC setup in us-west-2, VPCs A and B must reach external SaaS apps via private endpoints only, while all outbound internet egress is inspected by a centralized firewall in VPC C. Propose a beginner-friendly design using Transit Gateway, PrivateLink, and Route 53 Resolver DNS. Describe routing, DNS resolution, and observability?
questions.answer: Attach VPCs A, B, and C to a single Transit Gateway, place a security VPC C with a managed firewall, and route all Internet egress from A and B through the firewall via TGW route tables. For SaaS, dep
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
Tests understanding of multi-account/VPC design, traffic steering, PrivateLink, and DNS-based access.

## Key Concepts
- Transit Gateway attachments across accounts
- PrivateLink endpoints for SaaS
- Route 53 Resolver DNS and private DNS
- Centralized firewall in a shared VPC
- Observability with VPC flow logs and firewall logs

## Code Example
```javascript
// Example: pseudo-steps for config (not deployable as-is)
// 1. Create TGW, attach A, B, C
// 2. Create PrivateLink endpoints in A/B for SaaS
// 3. Enable private DNS in Route 53
// 4. Route egress from A/B via C firewall
```

## Follow-up Questions
- How would you validate egress flow and DNS resolution end-to-end?
- What changes if SaaS supports only public endpoints?
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
  A[VPC A] --> TG[Transit Gateway]
  B[VPC B] --> TG
  TG --> F[Firewall in VPC C]
  F --> Internet[Internet]
  A --> PrivateLinkA[PrivateLink SaaS A]
  B --> PrivateLinkB[PrivateLink SaaS B]

questions.question: Two AWS accounts across us-east-1 and us-west-2 host a data science platform with multiple VPCs. Design a scalable, secure network that minimizes cross-region data transfer, keeps east-west private, and supports easy onboarding of new accounts. Requirements: hub Transit Gateway across regions, centralized outbound egress via a shared firewall stack, private access to S3/data lake using PrivateLink with Private DNS, IPv6 dual-stack readiness, and automatic account onboarding. Explain architecture, routing, firewall policy model, cost controls, and observability?
questions.answer: Propose a two-region hub design using per-region Transit Gateways connected to a central firewall VPC. Route all outbound Internet and SaaS access via the firewall; use PrivateLink + Private DNS for S
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
Real-world multi-account, multi-region networks require scalable hub-and-spoke with centralized egress and private inter-VPC traffic.

## Key Concepts
- Transit Gateway hub across regions; VPC attachments; inter-region routing
- Central firewall stack (Network Firewall) with private endpoints
- PrivateLink + Private DNS for S3/data lake access
- IPv6 dual-stack readiness and observability

## Code Example
```javascript
// Sketch: CDK-like pseudo-setup for TGW attachment (not runnable)
class TGWAttachment { constructor(region, vpc) { /* attach VPC to TGW */ } }
```

## Follow-up Questions
- How would you implement automated onboarding of new accounts? What IAM and SCPs?
- How would you monitor and troubleshoot cross-region latency and firewall load?
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
  EastVPCs[VPCs - us-east-1]
  WestVPCs[VPCs - us-west-2]
  TGW_E[Transit Gateway - us-east-1]
  TGW_W[Transit Gateway - us-west-2]
  FW[Central Firewall VPC]
  S3P[PrivateLink to S3/Data Lake]
  DataLake[S3 Data Lake]
  Internet[Internet]

  EastVPCs -->|attaches to| TGW_E
  WestVPCs -->|attaches to| TGW_W
  TGW_E --> FW
  TGW_W --> FW
  FW --> Internet
  FW --> DataLake
  S3P --- DataLake

questions.question: In a single AWS account, two VPCs exist: a private app VPC (no Internet gateway) and a separate VPC hosting the patch bucket. You want the private VPC to pull software updates from S3 in the same region without any public Internet access, and you must restrict access to only the vendor-patches bucket. Design and describe the steps to implement an S3 VPC Endpoint with an endpoint policy, route table changes, and any security considerations?
questions.answer: Create an S3 VPC Endpoint (gateway type) in the private VPC, and add the private route table to point S3 traffic to that endpoint. Attach an endpoint policy that allows only actions on the bucket vend
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked

Tests understanding of private access to S3 using VPC Endpoints, plus endpoint policies and routing in a multi-subnet setup.

## Key Concepts

- S3 VPC Endpoint (gateway)
- Endpoint policy
- Route table associations
- Private subnet security
- Public Internet avoidance

## Code Example

```javascript
aws ec2 create-vpc-endpoint --vpc-id vpc-111111 --service-name com.amazonaws.us-east-1.s3 --route-table-ids rtb-222222 --policy-document '{"Statement":[{"Effect":"Allow","Principal":"*","Action":["s3:GetObject","s3:ListBucket"],"Resource":["arn:aws:s3:::vendor-patches","arn:aws:s3:::vendor-patches/*"]}]}'
```

## Follow-up Questions

- How would you adjust this policy for additional buckets?
- How do you test the endpoint from a private subnet?

questions.question: Design a two-region hub-and-spoke network for a SaaS platform with 3 AWS accounts per region and 4 VPCs per region. They require private east-west traffic between services, deterministic private access to S3/DynamoDB via PrivateLink, centralized firewall egress, and easy onboarding of new tenants via an account factory. Propose a design using Transit Gateway, PrivateLink, and centralized firewalling; detail routing, tenancy isolation, scaling, and observability?
questions.answer: Design a two-region hub-and-spoke with a core account hosting a Transit Gateway. Attach all regional VPCs, use PrivateLink for SaaS and private S3/DynamoDB access, and centralize egress through a regi
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked

Assesses ability to design scalable, segregated multi-account, multi-region networks with centralized control and tenant onboarding. It also tests service discovery, private connectivity, and observability in an advanced AWS networking scenario.

## Key Concepts

- Transit Gateway hub design across regions
- PrivateLink and VPC Endpoints
- Centralized firewall management (Network Firewall + Firewall Manager)
- Account factory and IAM RAM for cross-account sharing
- Observability: VPC Flow Logs, CloudWatch, OpenTelemetry

## Code Example

```javascript
// Terraform-esque pseudo
resource "aws_ec2_transit_gateway" "core" { ... }
resource "aws_ec2TransitGatewayAttachment" "region1" { ... }
```

## Follow-up Questions

- How would you scale TGW attachments to 100s of VPCs without TGW throttling?
- How would you handle tenant revocation and data isolation?
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
  A[Tenant Onboarding] --> B[TGW Attachment]
  B --> C[Region1 VPCs]
  B --> D[Region2 VPCs]
  C --> E[PrivateLink Endpoints]
  D --> E
  E --> F[SaaS DataStore]

questions.question: Design a two-region, multi-tenant SaaS network: per-tenant VPCs in Region A and Region B, all funneling to a centralized Transit Gateway and a regional Service VPC hosting API gateways and Network Firewall. Use PrivateLink for S3/DynamoDB, Route 53 private DNS for discovery, and an automated account factory for onboarding. Explain tenancy isolation, onboarding, cross-region failover, and observability?
questions.answer: Architect a two-region, multi-tenant SaaS: per-tenant VPCs in Region A and Region B, all funneling to a centralized TGW and a regional Service VPC with API gateway and Network Firewall. Use PrivateLin
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
Tests designing scalable, secure cross-region multi-tenant networks with tenancy isolation, automation, and observability.

## Key Concepts
- Transit Gateway as central spine across regions
- PrivateLink Endpoints and DNS-based service discovery
- Automated account factory for onboarding
- Tenant isolation via SG/NACLs and per-tenant VPCs
- Observability: Flow Logs, CloudWatch, Traffic Mirroring

## Code Example
```javascript
// pseudo
const vpc = new Vpc({ tenancy: 'tenantA' });
// attach to TGW, create PrivateLink endpoints, set DNS
```

## Follow-up Questions
- How would you enforce per-tenant egress policies at scale?
- How would you test failover between regions?
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
  A[Region A: Tenant VPCs] -->|TGW| B[Regional Service VPC]
  C[Region B: Tenant VPCs] -->|TGW| B
  B --> D[Network Firewall]
  B --> E[PrivateLink: S3/DynamoDB]
  D --> F[SaaS Services]

questions.question: In two AWS accounts with two VPCs in a single region, internal services require private DNS resolution for api.internal and auth.internal without public endpoints. Design a simple cross‑account Route 53 Resolver setup using a central DNS hub VPC with inbound/outbound endpoints and forwarding rules, and outline onboarding for new VPCs?
questions.answer: Deploy a central DNS hub VPC with Route 53 Resolver configured. Create outbound endpoints in each account's VPC to forward queries to the hub, and inbound endpoints in the hub to resolve api.internal and auth.internal queries. Use Resource Access Manager (RAM) to share the hub's resolver rules with spoke accounts, and configure forwarding rules for specific internal domains to prevent DNS leakage.
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked

Tests the candidate's understanding of practical cross-account DNS resolution using Route 53 Resolver; evaluates hub architecture design, RAM sharing implementation, and security controls for private DNS.

## Key Concepts

- Route 53 Resolver with inbound/outbound endpoints
- Centralized DNS hub VPC architecture
- Resource Access Manager (RAM) for cross-account sharing
- Private DNS forwarding rules for specific domains
- Security controls to prevent DNS leakage to public resolvers

## Code Example

```bash
# AWS CLI snippet to create a forwarder rule
aws route53resolver \
  --create-resolver-rule \
  --name "internal-forward-rule" \
  --rule-type FORWARD \
  --domain-name "internal" \
  --target-ips IpAddress="10.0.1.100" \
  --resolver-endpoint-id "rslvr-inbound-12345"
```

## Onboarding New VPCs

1. Create outbound resolver endpoint in the new VPC
2. Accept RAM invitation for shared resolver rules
3. Associate the shared resolver rules with the VPC
4. Update route tables to route DNS traffic through the hub VPC
5. Test resolution of internal domains
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
  A[Account A VPC] --> B[DNS Hub VPC]
  C[Account B VPC] --> B
  B --> D[Inbound Endpoint]
  B --> E[Outbound Endpoint]

questions.question: In a two-region deployment (Region A and Region B) across two AWS accounts per region, tenants are isolated in VPCs attached to regional Transit Gateways. Design a DR-ready network that preserves private east–west traffic, ensures tenant isolation during regional outage, and enables automatic failover of control-plane services to the DR region. Propose TGW topology with a DR region, synchronized PrivateLink services, replicated firewall rules, and a testing/validation plan with telemetry?
questions.answer: Two regional Transit Gateways with per-tenant VPC attachments. A DR Transit Gateway in Region B hosts synchronized PrivateLink services and duplicated firewall policies via Firewall Manager. Control-plane endpoints utilize Route 53 health checks for automatic failover, while cross-region VPC peering maintains private east-west traffic. Tenant isolation is preserved through dedicated VPC attachments and security group replication during regional outages.
questions.explanation: This question evaluates multi-region disaster recovery readiness, tenant isolation strategies, and automation capabilities. Candidates should demonstrate understanding of per-tenant Transit Gateway attachments, cross-region service parity, automated policy replication mechanisms, DNS-based failover configurations, and comprehensive observability for reduced mean time to recovery. The response should also address testing methodologies and rollback procedures for DR scenarios.
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
  A[Region A TGW] --> B[Tenant VPCs A]
  A --> C[Region A Control-Plane]
  D[Region B DR TGW] --> E[Tenant VPCs B]
  F[Replicated PrivateLink Services]
  G[Replicated Firewall Policies]
  H[Route 53 Failover for Control-Plane]
  I[DR Activation & Validation]

questions.question: Design a DR-ready, multi-region network for a SaaS platform with 3 tenants per region, each tenant in its own VPC attached to a regional Transit Gateway. Propose topology to keep private east-west traffic between tenants and control plane across regions, enable automatic failover of the control-plane to DR region using PrivateLink, support tenant onboarding, and specify telemetry and testing plans?
questions.answer: Proposed architecture: Region A/B each feature a hub Transit Gateway with per-tenant VPC attachments; a DR region Transit Gateway provides cross-region private east-west connectivity. The control plane API is exposed via PrivateLink in the DR region, with DNS failover configuration ensuring automatic continuity. Tenant onboarding is automated through Infrastructure as Code templates that provision VPC attachments and apply consistent security policies across all regions.
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
This question evaluates advanced cross-region network design capabilities, specifically addressing multi-tenant isolation, disaster recovery orchestration, and automated failover mechanisms beyond basic hub-and-spoke topologies.

## Key Concepts
- Transit Gateway multi-region topology with per-tenant VPC attachments
- PrivateLink-based cross-region control plane access for secure connectivity
- Automatic failover with DNS-based service continuity
- Comprehensive telemetry: VPC Flow Logs, CloudWatch metrics, PrivateLink access logs
- Automated tenant onboarding with IaC templates and firewall policy replication

## Code Example
```javascript
// Pseudo-Terraform/CDK sketch illustrating cross-region PrivateLink service
const pl = new PrivateLink(...);
```

## Follow-up Questions
- How would you implement zero-downtime tenant migration between regions?
- What strategies would you use for cost optimization in this multi-region setup?
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
  A[Region A Tenant VPC] --> B[Region A TGW]
  C[Region B Tenant VPC] --> D[Region B TGW]
  E[DR Region TGW] --> F[Control Plane PrivateLink]
  B --> E
  D --> E

questions.question: Beginner-level: You operate a SaaS API in Account A, Region us-east-1. You must share the API with a partner in Account B using PrivateLink, with automatic DR failover to DR region us-west-2 and DNS-based failover via Route 53 private hosted zones. Design the minimal topology, specify resources (PrivateLink service, VPC endpoints, private DNS records) and a basic testing plan?
questions.answer: Expose the API privately via PrivateLink in Account A's VPC and publish a PrivateLink service; have Account B's VPCs create VPC Endpoints to consume it. Add a Private Hosted Zone in Route53 for servic
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
Tests PrivateLink cross-account exposure, private DNS discovery, and DR failover using Route 53 private hosted zones. It also covers basic observability and onboarding of a partner.

## Key Concepts
- PrivateLink service exposure across accounts
- VPC Endpoints as consumers
- Route 53 private hosted zones and DNS failover
- Cross-region DR planning and testing
- Basic telemetry (CloudWatch, VPC Flow Logs)

## Code Example
```bash
# Example commands (illustrative)
aws ec2 create-vpc-endpoint-configuration --service-name com.amazonaws.vpce.us-east-1.vpce-svc-12345678 --vpc-emails  --dry-run
```

## Follow-up Questions
- How would you test failover to DR and validate DNS failover behavior?
- What security controls would you apply to the PrivateLink service and endpoints?
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
A[Service VPC (Account A, us-east-1)] --> PV[PrivateLink service in A]
B[Partner VPC (Account B, us-east-1)] --> EP[VPC Endpoint in B]
PV --> EP
DNS[Route53 Private Hosted Zone] --> EP
DR[DR VPC (Account A, us-west-2)] --> PV

questions.question: Design a DR-ready topology for a SaaS platform with per-tenant VPCs attached to regional Transit Gateways in two AWS regions. Ensure private east-west traffic, tenant isolation during regional outage, and automatic control-plane failover to the DR region. Explain TGW topology, PrivateLink replication, DNS failover, cross-region storage replication, and telemetry-based validation. **Edge cases** considered?
questions.answer: Propose two regional TGWs with per-tenant VPC attachments to a central Service VPC in each region, mirroring PrivateLink services across regions, and a DNS failover to DR using private hosted zones. K
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
Tests DR across regions, tenant isolation, control-plane failover, and observability using TGW, PrivateLink, DNS, and telemetry.

## Key Concepts
- Multi-region TGW topology across accounts
- Cross-region PrivateLink replication and discovery
- Automated control-plane failover via DNS and routing
- Telemetry, auditing, and DR validation with FIS

## Code Example
```javascript
// Illustrative topology representation
const topology = {
  regions: ['us-east-1','us-west-2'],
  tgwAttachments: { 'us-east-1': ['tenantA','tenantB'], 'us-west-2': ['tenantC','tenantD'] }
};
```

## Follow-up Questions
- How would you test failover during a partial outage?
- What telemetry signals confirm successful DR restoration?

questions.question: Design a cross-region, multi-account SaaS network using AWS VPC Lattice for per-tenant service discovery and authorization across Region A and Region B. Tenants reside in isolated VPCs yet must privately reach a central API service in a hub region. Outline: tenant-to-service mapping with Lattice; inter-region PrivateLink; centralized firewall strategy; DR with DNS failover and telemetry; onboarding and revocation processes?
questions.answer: Leverage VPC Lattice to publish hub API as a service in both regions; map each tenant VPC as a lattice principal and attach per-tenant access policies. Connect tenant VPCs to Hub via PrivateLink inter
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
Assesses ability to design cross-region, multi-account tenant isolation with modern service discovery and secure inter-region calls.

## Key Concepts
- AWS VPC Lattice for cross-VPC service discovery and authorization
- PrivateLink for private inter-region API calls
- Centralized firewall strategy and telemetry
- DR strategy with DNS failover and tenant on-boarding/revocation

## Code Example
```javascript
// Pseudo infra sketch
const lattice = {
  hubService: { name: "HubAPI", regions: ["RegionA", "RegionB"] },
  tenants: [
    { id: "t1", vpc: "vpc-a1" },
    { id: "t2", vpc: "vpc-b1" }
  ],
  policies: [
    { tenant: "t1", actions: ["HubAPI:Invoke"] },
    { tenant: "t2", actions: ["HubAPI:Invoke"] }
  ]
}
```

## Follow-up Questions
- How would you rotate tenant credentials and revoke access efficiently?
- What failure modes exist in cross-region Lattice setups and mitigations?

questions.question: Scenario: A SaaS company hosts 5 tenants in 5 VPCs in Region us-east-1; all attach to a central Transit Gateway in a shared-services account. Each tenant must access a per-tenant PrivateLink API service while keeping strict east-west isolation. Design the topology, attach VPCs, implement per-tenant firewall rules, and provide telemetry to verify isolation and scalability. Include onboarding a new tenant?
questions.answer: Attach each tenant VPC to a hub TGW in the shared services account; create a per-tenant PrivateLink service and a corresponding VPC endpoint in the tenant VPC; enforce isolation via per-tenant Securit
questions.explanation:

```typescript
// CDK sketch for PrivateLink per-tenant (pseudo)
```

questions.question: In a two-region deployment for a multi-tenant SaaS, each region houses 4 tenant VPCs attached to a regional Transit Gateway, plus a central Service VPC hosting API gateways and a Firewall fleet. Design a DR-ready topology that keeps tenant traffic private to the local region, ensures isolation during regional outages, and enables automatic control-plane failover to the DR region via PrivateLink. Include routing, PrivateLink replication, firewall policy synchronization, tenant onboarding, telemetry, and a DR validation plan?
questions.answer: Plan a two-region hub-and-spoke: 4 tenant VPCs per region attach to regional TGW with a central Service VPC hosting APIs and a Firewall fleet. Connect tenants to the Service VPC via PrivateLink; repli
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
Tests ability to design DR-ready, private east-west traffic with multi-region PrivateLink and centralized firewalling, plus tenant-onboarding and observability.

## Key Concepts
- Regional Transit Gateways and hub-and-spoke design
- PrivateLink service replication across DR
- Cross-region firewall policy synchronization
- DR validation and telemetry plan

## Code Example
```yaml
# Pseudo Terraform-like snippet illustrating PrivateLink replication to DR
resource "aws_vpc_endpoint_service" "svc_A" { ... }
resource "aws_vpc_endpoint" "ep_A" { ... product_service = aws_vpc_endpoint_service.svc_A.id }
# DR counterpart
resource "aws_vpc_endpoint_service" "svc_DR" { ... }
```

## Follow-up Questions
- How would you test DR failover with minimal tenant disruption?
- What metrics and alarms ensure drift-free PrivateLink and firewall policies across regions?

questions.question: Two-region SaaS with 4 tenant VPCs per region attached to regional TGWs. Design a DR-ready topology that keeps private east–west traffic during normal operations, ensures tenant isolation during regional outage, and enables automatic control-plane failover to the DR region. Specify: (a) TGW/VPC layout and route propagation, (b) PrivateLink service replication for the control plane API across regions, (c) per-tenant firewall/rules synchronization, (d) cross-region service discovery with Cloud Map and private DNS, (e) telemetry, validation, and failover testing plan, including rollback?
questions.answer: Leverage a two-region DR with 4 tenant VPCs per region attached to regional TGWs. Preserve private east–west with deliberate route propagation and enable automatic control-plane failover to DR via rep
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
Tests ability to design a DR topology that preserves tenant isolation, private traffic, control-plane continuity, and observability across regions using TGW, PrivateLink, Cloud Map, and Firewall Manager.

## Key Concepts
- Two-region DR topology with Transit Gateway and VPC attachments
- PrivateLink service replication for control-plane APIs across regions
- Per-tenant firewall policy synchronization and centralized management
- Cross-region service discovery via Cloud Map and private DNS
- Telemetry, validation, and rollback/testing plan

## Code Example
```javascript
// Pseudo-CDK snippet: replicate PrivateLink service in DR region and wire endpoints
const drRegion = getDRRegion();
const plService = new PrivateLinkService(stack, 'ControlPlane', { /*...*/ });
plService.replicateTo(drRegion);
```

## Follow-up Questions
- How would you validate failover with tenants in-flight?
- How to scale firewall policy synchronization as tenants grow?
- What metrics indicate a healthy DR transition and rollback readiness?

questions.question: Design a DR-ready, two-region, multi-account AWS networking solution where each tenant sits in its own VPC connected to a regional Transit Gateway in Region A and Region B. Include an on-premises Direct Connect link via a DX Gateway, a central Analytics VPC reachable only through PrivateLink endpoints, automatic control-plane failover to DR region, and tenant onboarding. Outline TGW topology, PrivateLink replication, DX Gateway setup, observability, and DR validation?
questions.answer: Use dual-region hub-spoke TGWs with per-tenant VPC attachments; central Analytics VPC exposes a PrivateLink service replicated to DR region; Direct Connect gateway connects on-prem to primary and DR T
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
Tests cross-region DR, multi-account isolation, and PrivateLink replication with on-prem connectivity.

### Key Concepts
- Transit Gateway topology across regions
- PrivateLink service replication and endpoint policies
- Direct Connect Gateway cross-region reachability
- DR failover automation and telemetry

```javascript
aws ec2 create-vpc-endpoint-service-configuration --network-load-balancer-arns arn:aws:elasticloadbalancing:... --acceptance-required
```

### Follow-up Questions
- How would you validate tenant onboarding at scale during DR?
- How do you ensure policy synchronization across tenants during an outage?

questions.question: Beginner-level: In Account A, Region us-east-1, you host a private REST API exposed to tenants via PrivateLink. Tenants own their domain and want it mapped to the PrivateLink endpoint using Route 53 private hosted zones, with automatic DR failover to us-west-2. Design the minimal topology, cross-account sharing, and a testing plan?
questions.answer: Design a BYOD DNS PrivateLink topology: tenants own domains and map to a PrivateLink endpoint via Route 53 private hosted zones. Put a PrivateLink service in Account A/us-east-1, share via RAM, create
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
Tests understanding of PrivateLink cross-account sharing, per-tenant DNS mapping, and DR with DNS failover. Emphasizes practical wiring and observability.

## Key Concepts
- PrivateLink service ownership and RAM sharing
- Route 53 private hosted zones and private DNS
- Cross-region DR and DNS failover
- Telemetry and security boundaries

## Code Example
```javascript
// No code required for this design task
```

## Follow-up Questions
- How would you restrict tenant access to only specific API paths? 
- How would you automate adding new tenants via Terraform or CDK?
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
A[Tenants VPCs] -->|PrivateLink| B[PrivateLink Service (Account A us-east-1)]
B --> C[Private DNS in Tenant Private Hosted Zone]
D[DR Region us-west-2] --> E[DR PrivateLink Service]
E --> F[DR Private DNS Zone]

questions.question: You operate a two-region SaaS with 20 tenants; each tenant has a dedicated VPC in Region A and Region B attached to per-region Transit Gateways. Design a DR-ready onboarding flow where a central Onboarding Service in a Service VPC uses PrivateLink to onboard/offboard tenants in both regions, with automatic DR failover of the control plane and tenant data paths staying local. Outline TGW topology, PrivateLink replication, DX connectivity, DNS failover, telemetry, and a DR validation plan?
questions.answer: Design a DR-ready two-region SaaS architecture supporting 20 tenants, where each tenant has dedicated VPCs in Region A and Region B connected to per-region Transit Gateways. A central Onboarding Service in a Service VPC exposes a PrivateLink API for tenant provisioning, with automatic DR failover of the control plane while tenant data paths remain local to their respective regions.
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked

Tests ability to design cross-region onboarding, tenancy isolation, and DR failover using PrivateLink and Transit Gateways, while incorporating automation, observability, and validation processes.

## Key Concepts

- Multi-region DR strategy with automatic failover
- Per-tenant VPCs connected to regional Transit Gateways
- Central Onboarding Service VPC exposing PrivateLink API
- Direct Connect connectivity considerations for DR readiness
- Telemetry, health checks, and DR validation workflow

## Code Example

```
# Example (high level)
Resources:
  OnboardServiceVPC:
    Type: AWS::EC2::VPC
    Properties:
      CidrBlock: 10.0.0.0/16
      EnableDnsSupport: true
      EnableDnsHostnames: true
```
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
  A[Region A TGW] --> B[Tenant VPCs A]
  C[Region B TGW] --> D[Tenant VPCs B]
  E[Service VPC Onboarding] -->|PrivateLink| B
  E -->|PrivateLink| D
  F[DX Connection] --> E
  G[Route 53 Private DNS] --> B & D

questions.question: In a two-region SaaS deployment, each tenant owns a VPC in Region A and a mirrored VPC in Region B, both attached to their region’s Transit Gateway. Tenant onboarding is automated via an account factory. Design an end-to-end onboarding workflow that creates/attaches VPCs, configures TGW attachments and route tables, and exposes per-tenant PrivateLink endpoints to a central Analytics VPC. Include DR failover of the control plane and telemetry?
questions.answer: Automate the end-to-end onboarding workflow using an account factory with infrastructure-as-code (CDK/Terraform). For each new tenant: provision mirrored VPCs in Region A and Region B, attach each VPC to its region's Transit Gateway, configure subnets with appropriate route propagations, and expose per-tenant PrivateLink endpoints to the central Analytics VPC. Implement control plane DR failover using an active-passive configuration across regions with automated health checks and failover triggers. Enable comprehensive telemetry including CloudWatch metrics, VPC Flow Logs, and X-Ray tracing for monitoring the onboarding workflow and tenant connectivity.
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
  Onboard(Onboard Tenant) --> VPC_A[Region A VPCs]
  Onboard --> TGW_A[Region A TGW Attachment]
  Onboard --> VPC_B[Region B VPCs]
  VPC_A --> Analytics_A[Per-tenant PrivateLink to Analytics VPC]
  VPC_B --> Analytics_B[Per-tenant PrivateLink to Analytics VPC]
  Onboard --> DR[DR Failover of Control Plane]
  DR --> Route53[Route53 Health Checks & Failover]

questions.question: Two-region, multi-account SaaS: every tenant has a dedicated VPC attached to a regional Transit Gateway in Region A or Region B. Design a centralized telemetry fabric that aggregates VPC Flow Logs and firewall logs to a shared data lake via Kinesis Data Firehose, with DR failover of the telemetry stack and guaranteed data integrity?
questions.answer: Publish per-tenant VPC Flow Logs and Firewall logs to a regional Logging VPC, funnel through a Transit Gateway to a centralized Kinesis Data Firehose in each region, and write to a shared S3 data lake with cross-region replication for disaster recovery.
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
This question probes the ability to design a cross-region telemetry pipeline that preserves tenant isolation while enabling disaster recovery capabilities and ensuring data integrity during failover scenarios.

## Key Concepts
- Cross-region telemetry fabric across multiple AWS accounts
- Ingestion and aggregation of VPC Flow Logs and firewall logs
- Transit Gateway routing and cross-region data flow architecture
- Kinesis Data Firehose to S3 data lake with replication strategies
- KMS encryption and fine-grained IAM role-based access control
- Disaster recovery canary testing and data integrity validation mechanisms

## Code Example
```bash
# Example: create an encrypted Firehose delivery stream targeting S3
aws firehose create-delivery-stream \
  --delivery-stream-name telemetry-logs-stream \
  --s3-destination-configuration BucketName=shared-data-lake \
  --role-arn arn:aws:iam::account:role/FirehoseDeliveryRole \
  --encryption-configuration NoEncryptionConfig=KMS \
  --kms-master-key-arn arn:aws:kms:region:account:key/key-id
```
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
  TenantVPC[Tenant VPC] --> TGW[Regional TGW]
  TGW --> Firehose[Central Firehose]
  Firehose --> DataLake[S3 Data Lake]
  DataLake --> DR[DR Region Replication]

questions.question: In a two-region, multi-account SaaS deployment, each tenant resides in its own VPC connected to a shared Transit Gateway in each region. Central Analytics is exposed as a PrivateLink endpoint in a Shared Services VPC and shared to tenants via RAM. The DR region must auto-takeover control-plane using Route 53 failover and PrivateLink. Outline topology, onboarding, DNS strategy, telemetry, and a DR verification plan. How would you implement this end-to-end?
questions.answer: Design two-region, multi-account network: per-region TGWs with tenant VPC attachments; Analytics API exposed as a PrivateLink service in a Shared Services VPC and shared to tenants via RAM; use Route
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
This question probes expertise in cross-region PrivateLink, RAM, and DR orchestration in multi-account setups.

## Key Concepts
- Transit Gateway topology with per-region attachments
- AWS RAM PrivateLink service sharing across accounts
- Private DNS for internal tenant resolution
- Route 53 failover for DR control-plane
- Observability and automated DR validation

## Code Example
```hcl
# Minimal PrivateLink service and RAM share example (conceptual)
resource "aws_vpc_endpoint_service" "analytics" {
  vpc_id = "<shared-services-vpc-id>"
  network_load_balancer_arns = ["arn:aws:elasticloadbalancing:region:acct:loadbalancer/analytics-nlb"]
}
resource "aws_ram_resource_share" "analytics_share" {
  name = "AnalyticsPrivateLinkShare"
}
resource "aws_ram_principal_association" "tenant_access" {
  resource_share_arn = aws_ram_resource_share.analytics_share.arn
  principals         = ["arn:aws:iam::<tenant-account-id>:root"]
}
```

## Follow-up Questions
- How would you ensure tenant isolation as the number of tenants scales to thousands?
- What changes if some tenants require data residency constraints per region?
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
  TenantVPCs --> TGW[Transit Gateway]
  TGW --> AnalyticsService[Analytics PrivateLink Service]
  AnalyticsService --> DRFailover[Route 53 DR Failover]
  TenantVPCs --> DNS[Private DNS Zones]

questions.question: A multinational bank operates 6 VPCs across 3 AWS accounts in two regions. They want to centralize north-south internet egress for security inspection, keep east-west traffic private, minimize inter-region data transfer costs, and streamline onboarding of new accounts. Propose a hub-and-spoke design using AWS Transit Gateway, Network Firewall, and VPC Endpoints. Describe routing, policy model, and observability considerations?
questions.answer: Adopt a per-region hub-and-spoke with a Transit Gateway and a central Network Firewall VPC. Attach all VPCs to the TGW, route outbound to the firewall for inspection, and use S3/DynamoDB VPC Endpoints
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
Assesses ability to design scalable, compliant network with centralized inspection and cross-account onboarding.

## Key Concepts
- Per-region Transit Gateway hub-and-spoke design
- Centralized Network Firewall policy management
- VPC Endpoints to eliminate public internet egress
- Automated onboarding via AWS Organizations and TGW attachments
- Centralized observability using CloudWatch and S3 logs

## Code Example
```javascript
// Illustrative high-level design structure (JS object)
const design = {
  regions: ["us-east-1", "eu-west-1"],
  tgwPerRegion: true,
  firewallVpc: "netfw-vpc",
  attachments: ["vpc-a", "vpc-b", "vpc-c"]
};
```

## Follow-up Questions
- How would you verify there is no unrestricted internet egress across accounts?
- What changes would you make to support a third region with minimal rework?
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
  TGW[Transit Gateway] --> VPCsAttach[Attach VPCs]
  VPCsAttach --> Firewall[Network Firewall]
  Firewall --> Egress[Centralized egress to inspection]
  VPCsAttach --> Endpoints[EndPoints to S3/DynamoDB]

questions.question: In a multi-account AWS environment with four accounts (prod, dev, staging, shared-services) and two regions, internal services (e.g., app.internal, db.internal) must resolve to private IPs across accounts, with public DNS unchanged for customers. Propose a scalable private DNS design using a private hosted zone and Route 53 Resolver (inbound/outbound as needed). Explain setup steps, minimal cross-account boundaries, and basic validation methods?
questions.answer: Create a private hosted zone and share/link it to all VPCs. Deploy inbound endpoints in client VPCs and an outbound endpoint in shared-services to forward to the zone. Enable DNS resolution in each VP
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
Tests practical use of Route 53 Resolver for cross-account private DNS, a common operational need.

## Key Concepts
- Private Hosted Zones across accounts
- Route 53 Resolver inbound/outbound endpoints
- Cross-account delegation and monitoring

## Code Example
```javascript
// No code required for this task; configuration happens in AWS Console/CLI
```

## Follow-up Questions
- How would you scale this to 3 regions?
- How would you handle zone transfers and failover?

questions.question: An enterprise runs 4 AWS accounts across 2 regions with 10 VPCs. They require centralized north-south internet egress through a firewall inspection stack, private east-west traffic, cross-region replication, and scalable SaaS access via PrivateLink. Design an end-to-end network using Transit Gateway, VPC Endpoints, Private DNS, and optional Direct Connect/Interconnect. Describe routing, policy model, failover, and observability considerations?
questions.answer: Hub Transit Gateway design: a shared TGW with a central inspection VPC that all VPCs attach to, routing north-south traffic through a firewall stack for egress filtering. Use VPC Endpoints and Private
questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked

Evaluates design of a scalable, multi-account, multi-region network with centralized security, private interconnects, and SaaS access.

## Key Concepts

- Hub-and-spoke Transit Gateway design across accounts and regions
- Centralized inspection VPC with firewall stack for north-south egress
- PrivateLink and VPC Endpoints for SaaS and AWS services
- Route 53 Resolver private DNS for hybrid naming and DNSSEC considerations
- Inter-region TGW connectivity for east-west traffic
- Observability via VPC Flow Logs, TGW flow logs, Reachability Analyzer, and CloudWatch metrics
- Cost/failover tradeoffs including Direct Connect vs VPN, NAT costs, and data transfer pricing

## Code Example

```javascript
// Pseudo-CDK snippet to illustrate hub TGW and VPC attachments
```

## Follow-up Questions

- How would you verify reachability and failover during a regional outage?
- What changes would you make to add a new region or bulk account onboarding?
questions.diagram:
flowchart TD
  Hub[Hub Transit Gateway] --> VPCs[Attached VPCs]
  Hub --> Firewall[Inspection VPC (firewall stack)]
  Firewall --> Internet[Central Internet egress]
  Hub --> SaaS[SaaS PrivateLink endpoints]
  Hub --> InterRegion[Inter-region TGW peering]
  VPCs -->|east-west| InterRegion
